Dispute_Type: Patent infringement dispute between brand-name and generic drug manufacturers
Legal_Issue: Whether the generic drug manufacturers infringed the '380 Patent for lovastatin
Governing_Law: Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations, Sections 5 and 6
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed significant yield improvements using Coniothyrium fuckelii alone; sterilization procedures were adequate
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicants to show that non-infringement allegations are unjustified
Credibility_Factor: Applicants' contamination argument rejected based on scientific evidence
Legal_Rule: Section 5 and 6 of the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations govern allegations of non-infringement and prohibition orders
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under the Patent Act and associated regulations
Grounds_for_Claim: Merck Frosst claimed generic manufacturers would infringe their patent for producing lovastatin
Outcome_on_Merits: Non-infringement allegations justified; Merck's applications dismissed
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Process followed regulatory requirements; burden properly allocated
Key_Evidence_Considered: Yield data from Coniothyrium fuckelii; adequacy of sterilization procedures
Legal_Framework: Patent Act and Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Challenging the validity of non-infringement allegations by generics
Defendant_Response: Contamination claim rejected; non-infringement supported by evidence
Outcome: Applications dismissed; costs awarded to respondents
Decision_Authority: Federal Court or relevant judicial body under Canadian patent law
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of market entry of generic lovastatin until patent expiry
Legal_Provision: Sections 5 and 6, Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Authority: Patent Act, Canadian intellectual property law
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 5 and Section 6 of the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Allegation of non-infringement based on microbial contamination was unsupported
